awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Computational  Studies of Weyl Semimetals: Disorder, Correlations and Topological Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational and theoretical research and education towards discovering and studying the properties of new Weyl semimetals. These are new types of materials that have been recently proposed theoretically and are now beginning to be discovered. They are very poor conductors in their bulk but have highly conductive metallic surfaces. These materials are special in that their surface enjoys what is called topological protection, meaning that it cannot be changed without destroying the bulk material. In most materials, surfaces can be chemically altered as they tend to pick up impurities from the environment, which in turn interfere with how materials conduct electricity, a crucial feature for applications in any electronic device. However, the topologically protected surfaces of Weyl semimetals are robust to impurities. 

This research project aims to develop methods for finding new Weyl semimetals, and for understanding their properties using computer-based simulations. The close competition between various degrees of freedom of the electrons in these materials makes their study particularly challenging, but also holds great promise for new functionalities.

The research will lead to new methods, algorithms, and software that will enhance and simplify our ability to carry out material-specific studies and to promote the gradual improvement of materials by computer-aided design, thus shortening currently expensive and inefficient trial-and-error procedures. Developing scientific software tools that incorporate computer programs into a user-friendly interface lowers the barrier to entry for the computational exploration of the properties of quantum materials. The development of these user-friendly interfaces will also facilitate the teaching of elementary theories of topological materials at advanced undergraduate and graduate levels, thereby enhancing University curricula.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports the development of computational approaches that are based on density-functional theory combined with dynamical-mean-field and perturbation theories, which will allow finding new topological semimetals and studying their single-particle spectra, transport, magnetic, and superconducting properties. Guided by similarities between crystal structures and topological features of known systems, realizations of the band inversion mechanism between electronic states of different parity, hybridization effects between partially filled strongly correlated states with filled or empty topological energy bands, chemical valence arguments and physical intuition, a high-throughput screening of materials for their topological properties will be performed in the infinite space of chemically allowed compounds using computer-based simulations.

These findings will allow identifying new topological materials, such as Weyl semimetals, and, in particular, those with only Weyl nodes and no other Fermi surface states. Such discoveries could motivate further experimental studies of the chiral anomaly and topological superconductivity. Theoretical and computational approaches to predict and study complex behavior in these systems would potentially influence the design of quantum materials with unique characteristics that rely on topological protection of states, which are at the frontier of materials science.

The research will lead to new methods, algorithms, and software that will enhance and simplify our ability to carry out material-specific studies and to promote the gradual improvement of materials by computer-aided design, thus shortening currently expensive and inefficient trial-and-error procedures. Developing scientific software tools that incorporate computer programs into a user-friendly interface lowers the barrier to entry for the computational exploration of the properties of quantum materials. The development of these user-friendly interfaces will also facilitate the teaching of elementary theories of topological materials at advanced undergraduate and graduate levels, thereby enhancing University curricula.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research related to our understanding of Weyl semimetal materials, a new type of topological condensed matter, was the subject of this NSF award. Weyl semimetals host highly unusual states of electrons such as bulk band crossings behaving similar to Dirac monopoles as well as surface Fermi arcs that can lead to intriguing transport properties, e.g., chiral anomaly induced negative magnetoresistance and a semiquantized anomalous Hall effect. Understanding their behavior is the frontier of material science that currently attracts a great interest due to its promise in finding new electronic devices. 


During years 2019-2022 covering this award, a signficant progress has been made to discover such materials and describe their properties using newly developed computer algorithms, codes and simulations paired with the best available experimental techniques. Our findings included the discovery of colossal anomalous Nernst effect in kagome ferromagnet UCo0.8Ru0.2Al, prediction of Weyl smemimetal-to-topological insulator phase transition in actinide compound UNiSn, observation of highly dissipationless exciton transport at the surface of topological insulators that implies the formation of superfluid-like exciton condensate, experimental verification of large electron-phonon coupling, which we proposed to give rise to the exotic p-wave nematic superconducting pairing in the Copper doped Bi2Se3. We also found the existence of topological nodal lines in CeTX3 series of compounds that have a signicant effect on the Fermi surface spin structure and its implication for a possible topological superconductivty.


Several computer codes and software have been developed. These tools combine electronic structure theory and dynamical mean field theory methods in order to calculate various topological invariants and locate positions of the Weyl points in materials that exhibit strong correlation effect. The software has been coded with help of graduate students that were supported by this grant and is freely available on the internet for the use by the scientific community.   Our comprehensive treatment of many compounds using these computational tools was a critical first step in high-throughput searches of correlated topological materials addressing an interplaty between the behavior of electronic correlations, unconventional superconductivity and topological properties.


As a broader impact, this research allowed us to construct new methods, algorithms, and the software which simplifies our abilities to discover new materials and carry out studies of their physical properties. Our developed scientific computer codes for studying non-trivial topological properties allowed their explorations by non-experts, material scientists, experimentalists and graduate students. User friendly interfaces that were build in the course of this award enhanced our University curriculum by allowing us to teach elementary theories of topological materials at advanced undergraduate and graduate levels. The educational mode enhanced infrastructure for research and education as well as broadened participation of underrepresented groups in materials research.

Modified by: Sergey Savrasov
